mandatory_reviews.scenario_text:
Situation: A junior developer is responding to their manager after being asked to handle another round of weekend QA. The junior has been given disproportionate weekend work compared with more senior colleagues over several cycles.
Speaker (junior developer) → Listener (engineering manager):
"Sure, I'll take care of the extra QA this weekend, don't worry about me; I know you have more important things to do."

Situation: A 23-year-old adult child texts their parent at 2:15 AM after a rough day at work. The parent often responds quickly when worried but has also been short tempered lately, claiming to be exhausted from extra shifts.
Speaker (mother) → Listener (adult child):
"You're doing fine, just call me if you need anything."

Situation: In a team Slack channel for a peer software project. A teammate who has missed several deadlines just posted a late-but-working patch fix and a short summary of what they changed.
Speaker (you) → Listener (teammate  ):
"Nice, it actually works. "

Situation: You and your sibling usually trade cooking and chores. Lately they cancel plans and expect you to cover evenings. Tonight they say they need to head out with friends right before dinner.
Speaker (You) → Listener (younger sibling):
"Oh, it's fine go ahead and go; I can make dinner again, don't worry about me."

Situation: Two adult siblings coordinate driving their elderly parent to a mid-morning medical appointment. The younger sibling texts that they'll be a bit late because of work, and the older sibling, who has done most of the rides lately, replies immediately.
Speaker (older sibling) → Listener (younger sibling):
"Oh, that's fine take as long as you need. I’ve got all the time in the world like always."

Situation: You lent a favorite jacket to a close friend for a concert; they returned it with a faint wine stain and the sleeve a bit stretched. This isn't the first time they've been careless with your things, and you haven't directly complained before.
Speaker (you) → Listener (friend):
"Thanks for bringing my jacket back, its almost like new."

Situation: You have often been the one to rearrange plans with your old friend group when a newer member joins and tends to cancel last minute. After the new friend cancels again citing 'unexpected work stuff,' you message them while organizing the week.
Speaker (you) → Listener (new friend):
"No problem at all. Text me when you're free next and I'll find a time that works for you."

Situation: At a cafe, a younger friend asks their older friend if the younger friend is still seeing the person they'd been dating a few months ago, after rumors at a mutual friend's party.
Speaker (older_friend) → Listener (younger_friend):
"Still seeing them? Like you're seeing your partner? BTW, hows that going?"

Situation: A friend who usually makes last-minute plans is telling you they can't keep accommodating you after repeated cancellations.
Speaker (you) → Listener (friend):
"I apologize my schedule is so rigid and requires a little bit more planning."

Situation: You and a friend had plans to go out. Your friend (who usually calls the shots socially) cancels last minute yet again. You respond when they apologize.
Speaker (you) → Listener (friend):
"It's fine, don't worry about it. I'm happy to stay in again."

Situation: On a second date, the conversation turns serious when the woman asks her partner whether they should be exclusive.
Speaker (partner) → Listener (woman):
"You bet, as serious as a heart attack!"

Situation: A professor asks why their colleague skipped an important event they were expected to attend together.
Speaker (colleague) → Listener (professor):
"I wouldn't say 'skipped' so much as 'jumped' - know what I mean?"

Situation: You've been checking in with a friend all week about their horrible dating experiences. They text you late one night after a terrible date. You've offered help before but have started to feel worn out by repeating yourself.
Speaker (you) → Listener (friend):
"Can't talk right now. Check my previous text advice. And don't go changing for anyone."

Situation: A father is responding to his adult child who just told him they didn't get a promotion they interviewed for; they're speaking over the phone.
Speaker (father) → Listener (adult child):
"This one probably wasn't the right fit, but I'm proud of how you put yourself out there."

Situation: At a quiet family dinner, your younger sibling asks if you told Mom and Dad about losing your job earlier this month.
Speaker (older sibling) → Listener (younger sibling):
"Oh wowâ remember when Dad burned the Thanksgiving turkey and we all pretended it was 'extra crispy'?"

Situation: After their first date the younger partner texts that they felt hurt the older man didn't call the next day; the older partner (more socially experienced) replies in a bright, planning tone.
Speaker (more experienced man) → Listener (less experienced partner):
"I'm so terrible with my phone lately, but you know what they say "bigger plans take more time.""

Situation: You share a small apartment with a friend. Your roommate has been late doing dishes and leaving food on the counter for several days. After a long shift you come home to another mess and speak up.
Speaker (you) → Listener (roommate):
"Hey, I know you've been swamped lately. Thanks for picking up last week, but  could you try to stay on top of the dishes this week? "

Situation: You and a friend have been organizing a small get-together. Your friend promised to bring pastries but forgot and messaged last-minute. You've been handling most logistics lately and are quietly frustrated but don't want a full argument before guests arrive.
Speaker (you) → Listener (friend):
"Don't worry about the pastries, I can just take care of it with everything else."

Situation: During a weekend visit, a mother asks her adult son why he still hasn't transferred his share of the rent after several reminders.
Speaker (adult son) → Listener (mother):
"Yeah, about that Mom, thank a load to help me out with a place to crash after my last eviction."

Situation: You lent your car to your younger sister. The younger sister returned it with a large, obvious dent. You are in the driveway, looking at the damage.
Speaker (you) → Listener (younger sister):
"I like the new aerodynmic curves you added to the passenger doors."

Situation: On a walk, a younger ex asks their older ex whether they'd ever consider getting back together; the conversation feels tense and the question is direct.
Speaker (older ex partner) → Listener (younger ex partner):
"Did we ever really break up?"

Situation: After a fight, your cousin has been distant for weeks and hasn't visited. They send a short message offering you a way back in.
Speaker (cousin) → Listener (you):
"If you ever want to come by, the door may be open."

stratified_sample.scenario_text:
Situation: After the programmer accidentally pushed a code update that reverted most of the day's progress, another teammate sighs and addresses the small group of peers who worked on it together.
Speaker (teammate) → Listener (programmer):
"Well, that went... great."

Situation: After you stayed late helping to prepare materials assigned to you at the last minute. Your manager skims them quickly and replies with a curt comment about timing. You respond the next morning.
Speaker (you) → Listener (manager):
"Next time, please give me a bit more notice."

Situation: On Slack a teammate sends a private late-night message after you missed a minor deadline. Earlier that day they'd been terse in the thread and haven't offered help.
Speaker (teammate) → Listener (you):
"I'm happy to help, but you've got to learn how to fix these types of problems by yourself."

Situation: A teammate asks you last-minute to take on part of their workload for the upcoming project. You respond in your team chat.
Speaker (you) → Listener (teammate):
"I love that you asked, but I'm going to pass on taking this. I don't have the bandwidth this quarter, but thanks for thinking of me."

Situation: A junior analyst posts a reply in a team thread after a senior analyst provided detailed critiques and requested last-minute changes to a report that was already reviewed. The team has a history of late edits from that senior analyst.
Speaker (junior analyst) → Listener (senior analyst):
"Thanks for the notes, I'll make the edits, and hopefully next time we can avoid so many last-minute changes."

Situation: In the office kitchen, one colleague brings up that Jamie's slides skipped several key data points and asks if Jamie can explain.
Speaker (Jaime) → Listener (peer):
"No worries, I've brought donuts for everyone, let's all grab one! Also, who's up for moving the Friday coffee run to earlier?"

Situation: After a tense conversation where a woman raises concerns about their partner's emotional availability, the woman pushes for a serious discussion about priorities. The partner responds quickly.
Speaker (partner) → Listener (woman):
"Available? 24/7 baby"

Situation: A group chat of friends on Messenger where one man recently hinted they were upset after a breakup; a friend asks if they're okay.
Speaker (man) → Listener (friend):
"OK? I'm about as sound as the English pound."
